Let happier Bards, whose labouring breasts have known</br>Th' inspiring Muse, and transports not their own,</br>Whose rapid thoughts, like tow'ring Eagles, soar,</br>And eyes creation's ample bounds explore,</br>Awake, arise:  why are they mute so long,</br>When themes of glory claim the grateful song?</br>O'er every clime, where springs the fount of day,</br>Or western oceans quench the parting ray;</br>Where nearer suns the ductile ore mature,</br>Or hills the load of summer-snows endure;</br>Hath Britain's Genius stretcht his wide domain,</br>And faithless Gallia mourn'd her legions slain.</br>Who but hath seen the Trophies cheaply bought,</br>When Hawke hath conquer'd, and when Granby fought?</br>Who but hath heard how Wolfe untimely dy'd,</br>While Victory stood weeping at his side?</br>Haste, haste, ye Bards, and rapt to generous praise</br>Embalm the Heroe in immortal lays,</br>That distant times the wondrous tale may read,</br>And feel their souls inspir'd by every deed,</br>When valour faints may catch the patriot flame,</br>And burn for glory at his godlike name:</br>Thus to some tomb the pious Pilgrim flies</br>Where in cold earth the saint or martyr lies;</br>Where Fancy paints the Virtues weeping round,</br>And Inspiration guards the hallow'd ground;</br>There all entranc'd adores the sacred shrine,</br>Till his rapt bosom burns with flames divine.

But ah such themes so wondrous high demand</br>A Pindar's fire, a Pindar's voice, and hand:</br>Enough for me, thro' whose inglorious veins</br>The cold blood slowly creeps, in gentler strains</br>To sing returning Peace; nor Thou refuse,</br>O BUTE, this tribute of an humble Muse!</br>Thou, whose example sway'd the Royal Youth</br>To tread the paths of Virtue, and of Truth;</br>Whose early care destroy'd each noxious weed,</br>That lust for glory, and ambition breed;</br>But fed the plants, deriv'd from Heav'n above,</br>Whose milder fruits are Peace, and Joy, and Love.</br>Driv'n from her loathsome cave in blackest hell,</br>Where torturing tortur'd fiends she loves to dwell,</br>Up Discord rose, and wrapt in shades of night</br>Wing'd to this western world her baleful flight.</br>Her fiery eyeballs glar'd a ghastly blue,</br>And snaky locks dropt venom as she flew;</br>Her face was filthy foul, and stain'd with gore</br>Her garments hung in rags; a brand she bore</br>By Furies kindled, whence incessant fell </br>Infernal sparks of fire unquenchable.</br>Thus long she rag'd, and sow'd thro' every state</br>The seeds of faction, jealousy, and hate;</br>With madding storms of passion racks the mind,</br>And let loose wild Ambition on mankind.</br>But Thee, Germania, Thee she chiefly chose</br>Forlorn in dust to sit, and weep thy woes;</br>Thy comely visage markt with many a scar,</br>And blasted with the lightning brand of war;</br>Thy cities sackt, thy holy shrines defil'd,</br>Thy heroes butcher'd, and thy virgins spoil'd!</br>Where are thy charms, O poor forsaken Maid,</br>Harass'd by foes, by lawless friends betray'd?</br>Thy dowry where?  Lo, lo, the fruitful place</br>Is grown a barren, wasteful wilderness!</br>No more her fields, with golden harvests crown'd,</br>Or fill'd with lowing herds, rejoice around;</br>Her hills no more their purple vines display,</br>Whose swelling clusters drink the ripening ray,</br>War, horrid War, extends his iron reign,</br>And dreary Desolation sweeps the plain!

Hail, Britain, hail, fair seat of arts, and arms,</br>Secur'd by Heav'n from Mars's fierce alarms!</br>No foreign foes can shake thy stedfast Isle,</br>Impell'd by hatred, or allur'd by spoil;</br>While floating bulwarks guard thy trench, the main,</br>How vain their envy, and their rage how vain?</br>Hail Queen of Ocean, in whose placid eye</br>Smiles sweet Content, and heav'n-born Liberty!</br>'Tis thine to hear, far distant from thy shore,</br>The smould'ring thunders of the battle roar,</br>And bless'd in Peace with Heav'n's best gifts abound,</br>While war's fierce tempests rend the nations round:</br>Thus on the Andes, that stupendous chain</br>Of hills, whence tumbling torrents pour amain,</br>The hardy traveller sees, from Rica's brow,</br>The mad storm gathering all its rage below,</br>And charg'd with nitre, down the mountain's side,</br>Impetuous thunder' roll, and whirlwinds ride;</br>Dreadful they break, while he aloft enjoys</br>The calm serene of summer's evening-skies.

But not unmov'd Britannia's Monarch view'd</br>The storm descend in streams of christian blood;</br>Tho' Justice smil'd, and o'er his fav'rite head</br>Her purple wings exulting Conquest spread,</br>His soul abhorr'd the sight, and griev'd to buy</br>Fantastic glory at a price so high.</br>Curst be the man, who first a slave to fame,</br>And the vain transports of a sounding name,</br>Graspt at imperial pow'r, unsheath'd the blade,</br>Made war an art, and murd'rous death a trade;</br>But doubly curst, who lur'd by selfish views</br>The baleful art, and murd'rous trade pursues!
Far different schemes great GEORGE's care engage,</br>Rejoic'd to calm each faction's brutal rage,</br>In friendship's chain contending Kings to bind,</br>And pour the balm of concord on mankind.

To Britain's isle what blessings Peace may bring </br>In homespun strains full many a bard shall sing:</br>My Muse on fancy's eagle-pinion flies</br>To distant climes, where other suns arise;</br>Where groves of cedar wave, and trees unfold</br>Their dulcet stores of vegetable gold;</br>Where hills aspire, beneath whose lofty heads</br>Her humble glories sunborn Iris spreads;</br>And cataracts, rushing down the rocky steep,</br>Diffus'd in streams thro' vast savannahs sweep.</br>There unappall'd the tawny Indian roves</br>Thro' fragrant myrtle walks, and citron groves;</br>No poison'd arrow from the brake he fears,</br>No savage howl of war distracts his ears;</br>Secure he strays, and 'midst the conscious shade</br>Sings amorous descants to his sable maid.

O fair Laurentia, o'er whose fertile plains</br>No scourge of Heav'n, no purple Tyrant reigns!</br>Blest clime, on whom propitious fortune smil'd,</br>When Britain chose thee for her darling child!</br>Thy sons no more shall darkling grope their way,</br>Or blindly follow reason's glow-worm ray;</br>With healing wings the Sun of truth shall rise,</br>And light celestial beam from eastern skies;</br>The glorious Day-spring shall from high appear,</br>While Errour's ghastly phantoms shrink with fear.</br>Ev'n now methinks thy painted chiefs despise</br>Their pagan rites, and brutal sorceries;</br>Nor prone on earth the thunder's voice adore,</br>Nor bow to Ketan's monstrous idol more:</br>By pure Religion taught the sacred road,</br>That leads thro' Nature's path to Nature's God,</br>The One Supreme with holy love they fear,</br>And all the Gospel's wondrous truths revere;</br>On Faith's mysterious scale triumphant rise</br>Like sons of light, and claim their kindred skies:</br>Thus, Spenser sings, when Una, hapless maid,</br>Found a kind refuge in the green-wood shade,</br>A shaggy troop of Fauns, and Satyres came,</br>And gaz'd astonied on the beauteous dame:</br>When lo!  her wit such gentle force applies</br>To win them o'er from vain Idolatries;</br>From her blest lips such holy doctrines flow,</br>The savage race with pure devotion glow;</br>Receive in transport her celestial lore,</br>And burn with heav'nly flames unfelt before.</br>
